Items.Title: Roll Call
Invocation
Items.AgendaNote:
Delivered by: Rev. Dr. Johnson Rethinasamy, Evangelical Immanuel Lutheran Church Located 149-40 11th Avenue, Whitestone, N.Y.  11357.

Motion to spread the invocation in full upon the record by Council Member Vallone.
Items.MinutesNote:
The Invocation was delivered by: Rev. Dr. Johnson Rethinasamy, Evangelical Immanuel Lutheran Church, 149-40 11th Avenue, Whitestone, N.Y. 11357.



Council Member Vallone moved to spread the Invocation in full upon the Record.

Items.Title: Adoption of Minutes

Items.MinutesNote: Council Member Mendez moved that the Minutes of the Stated Meeting of June 11, 2014 and June 26, 2014 be adopted as printed.

Items.Title: Messages & Papers from the Mayor
Communications from City, County & Borough Offices

Communication from the Office of Management & Budget - Transfer City funds between two agencies in fiscal year 2014 to implement required changes to the City's expense budget to pay collective bargaining agreements in the Health and Hospital Corporation, pursuant to Section 107(b) of the New York City Charter. (MN-6)

Items.Title: Petitions and Communications
Land Use Call-Ups

By Council Member Johnson:
Pursuant to Rule 11.20b of the Council and §20-226 or §20-225 of the New York City Administrative Code, the Council resolves that the action of the Department of Consumer Affairs approving an unenclosed sidewalk café located at 24 Fifth Avenue, Borough of Manhattan, Community Board No. 2, Application no.  20145612 TCM shall be subject to review by the Council.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Zoning, Sidewalk café, 24 Fifth Ave, Manhattan (20145612 TCM)

Items.Title:
By Council Member Garodnick:
Pursuant to Rule 11.20b of the Council and §20-226 or §20-225 of the New York City Administrative Code, the Council resolves that the action of the Department of Consumer Affairs approving an unenclosed sidewalk café located at 254 Fifth Avenue, Borough of Manhattan, Community Board No. 5, Application no.  20145718 TCM shall be subject to review by the Council.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Zoning, Sidewalk café, 254 Fifth Ave, Manhattan (20145718 TCM)

Report of the Committee on Education
A Local Law to establish a program in relation to the employment of school bus drivers, attendants, dispatchers and mechanics by qualified employers.
Items.AgendaNote: Preconsidered - Coupled on GO with a Message of Necessity
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Establish a program in relation to the employment of school bus drivers, attendants, dispatchers and mechanics by qualified employers.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature to pass, and for the Governor to sign, legislation that would mandate employee safeguards for experienced bus drivers, attendants, dispatchers and mechanics as part of all current and future bus contracts.
Items.AgendaNote: Preconsidered - Adopted by the Committee on Education
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) declared the Resolution to be adopted.



The following Council Members formally abstained to vote on this item: 

Council Members Ulrich.



Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: Mandate employee safeguards for experienced bus drivers, attendants, dispatchers and mechanics as part of all current and future bus contracts.

A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the commissioner of correction, in coordination with the commissioner of health and mental hygiene, to post a quarterly report on its website regarding punitive segregation, restricted housing and clinical alternative to punitive segregation housing statistics for city jails
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by consent Roll Call.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York City Department of Correction to end the practice of placing individuals returning to City jails into punitive segregation, also known as solitary confinement, to complete time owed.
Items.AgendaNote: Preconsidered - Adopted by the Committee on Fire and Criminal Justice Services
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) declared the Resolution to be adopted.



The following 3 Council Members formally voted against this item: 

Council Members Ulrich, Vallone and Vacca.



Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: Dept of Correction to end the practice of placing individuals returning to City jails into punitive segregation, also known as solitary confinement, to complete time owed.

INTRODUCTION AND READING OF BILLS
A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to allowing ill or incapacitated street vendors to transfer their license to a family member.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Consumer Affairs
Items.MatterName: Allowing ill or incapacitated street vendors to transfer their license to a family member

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to amend the State Education Law to require that the New York City Department of Education equip all schools with adequate heating and air conditioning means to ensure an indoor temperature of 68 to 75 degrees Fahrenheit in the winter and 73 to 79 degrees Fahrenheit during the summer while school or summer school is in operation in the building.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
Items.MatterName: Require that the NYC Dept of Education equip all schools with adequate heating and air conditioning.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the installation and maintenance of electrical outlet safety devices and tamper-resistant receptacles in certain public parts of multifamily dwellings
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Electrical outlet safety devices and tamper-resistant receptacles.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to including a community notification requirement in the gun offender registry act.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Including a community notification requirement in the gun offender registry act.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon New York State Department of Education to include lessons on climate change in K-12 schools’ curriculum.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
Items.MatterName: DOE to include lessons on climate change in K-12 schools’ curriculum.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, legislation abolishing the minimum charge for water service imposed by the New York City Water Board.

Items.MatterName: Requiring DOE to report information regarding students receiving special education services.

Items.MinutesNote: At this point the Speaker (Council Member Mark-Viverito) made the following annoucements:

Whereupon on motion of the Speaker (Council Member Mark-Viverito), the Public Advocate (Ms. James) adjourned to meet again on Wednesday, September 10, 2014.



MICHAEL M. McSWEENEY, City Clerk

Clerk of the Council
The presence of a quorum was announced by The Public Advocate (Ms. James).
The Public Advocate (Ms. James) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such motion which was decided in the affirmative by the following vote:
At this point, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) declared that the aforementioned items were adopted and referred to the Committee on Land Use and to the appropriate Land Use Subcommittee.
